review_title: Get a job here at your own risk, but don't get too comfortable.
pros: Some of the kindest, most helpful people I have ever worked with are employed at BYU-Idaho. There are great amenities for employees such as access to excellent gym facilities, pool, library, etc. The pay is the best around and the benefits are great as well.
cons: It is very easy to get fired. I had co-workers and colleagues suddenly disappear because they were let go-often without warning. I was let go while I was away on vacation and not given a reason. HR told me that since Idaho is a "right to hire state" the university does not need a reason to fire anyone. There is no comparable work in the area so my family is going to have to move as soon as I can find a job somewhere. The university folks know this and yet they merrily fire their employees willy nilly.

job_title: MTC Zone Coordinator in Provo, UT
pros: great atmosphere and awesome coworkers. The MTC is very good about allowing you to take time off when you need it as long as you are a responsible employee and do a good job finding replacements when necessary, etc. I have also really enjoyed getting to know the other teachers and supervisors I work with. They are definitely very diverse and talented. This has been one of the best features of this job in my opinion. Aside from that... I would say that I enjoy how flexible they allow you to be with your teaching and class schedules. Very positive.
cons: at the mtc, there seems to be little accountability among teachers; their is no incentive to perform well. I rarely feel like I am given opportunities to grow and improve through feedback from my supervisors and peers. It seems that everyone (management included) is very very good about motivating the teachers but has yet to find a good way to ensure that they are teaching according to the standards and requirements outlined by the MTC. Also, there is rarely any kind of criticism or disciplinary action taken against those that abuse the system, are irresponsible, or bad employees in general. This was very frustrating at times.

job_title: Computer Support Specialist in Provo, UT
pros: I have worked on two different team's at BYU's Office of IT. This has been some of my most valuable work experience during my college career, and I have found mentors which have helped me a great deal in preparing for life after college. Each team has different schedule demands for their students, but in general, the schedule fits really well around your class schedule and other commitments. You get to do real work and learn on the job. Not a place to just sit and do homework, but I hate those kinds of jobs anyways -- I'd rather be stretched, learn, and grow. They treat you as a real employee.
cons: There are unfortunate politics that prevent some important changes and work from happening in the Office of IT. The full-timers take the hit so that the students are pretty sheltered from these politics, but it is sad to identify ways the organization needs to be changed in order to function better but know that politics won't let those things actually get fixed.

review_title: BYU is a great place to work if you’re willing to sacrifice for the cause.
pros: The atmosphere at BYU is great. You never need to fear being laid off.  It just doesn’t happen.  That can be good or bad depending on how you look at it.  BYU has great benefits.  They are very flexible with work schedules.  I’m sure this depends on the job you have and the area you work though.
cons: Salaries are low compared to similar jobs in the area.  They don’t provide a career path for many of their administrative positions.

pros: It's close. You get to work with great professors and people. Easy to balance school with work
cons: I have more expenses than ever before (tuition, housing and food), I'm working a much more technical job than ever before in my life (I work with engineering professors everyday to fabricate and test anything they may need in their research), yet I'VE NEVER BEEN PAID LESS. Ever since I was 16 I've been working for at least $10/hr. At BYU I've been paid $7.50, $8.50, and now $9.00/hr. It's pitiful how cheap this school can be and I don't think I'll be working on campus much longer. I'm not paid according to my worth and I need the money.

pros: You get to work in a great environment, and work with some really great people.
cons: Unfortunately, one student who is an area director chooses both the 2 directors and the replacement area director. So, that means that one student controls the distribution of 3 semesters worth of scholarships. Not exactly the best way to distribute money, because students are likely to simply pick their friends because they are their friends or worse, to pass over their friends because they are their friends, rather than pick the best person for the job. And they can say that they are "just following the Spirit" as the reason they made the decision.

review_title: Offered opportunities for real growth, though the limited pay was a concern
pros: I loved being able to run my own research team. The things I learned and the experience I gained are serving me well. Not all positions will be this way, but there was enough flexibility that I could take some of my work home and actually use my most productive time (late evening) while freeing up some daytime. I found myself sad to leave, knowing that my new employer was much different, but the time I spent there was good.
cons: Students can create a lot of turnover, while there are some people who have been there since the dawn of time that you may need to contend with. Pay was moderately dismal, even for my level. It's hard to keep employees engaged when they're not getting enough compensation - the ones who are really great are the ones that see some kind of purpose in their work there. Bureaucracy was a bit much (that's coming from a current federal employee).

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Provo, UT
pros: There were a lot of really fun people to work with. Direct supervisors can be fun if you are around a long time and if you get along with them well. Some of the time there is lots of time for homework.
cons: Major disconnect between policy makers and those who execute the policy. Management seems distant and disinterested in the company culture. It is really easy to not do a lot of work so those who do work carry much more of the load. Training sessions are ineffective and juvenile. They consistently ask for suggestions but make no changes. Recognition is awful, you can do great work but they will give you nothing or just a candy bar or something. They said if you did your job you would get three raises a year but they never can do the raise evaluations required for a raise so you never really get one.

pros: Many great reasons to work at BYU IF you are LDS.  Benefits are great including medical, dental, retirement, 401K, generous vacation and holiday schedules, free tuition, time off for devotionals and forums, etc.  Also, how many places can you work where you access to a post office, barber, florist, bookstore, library, food court, museums, workout facilities, racquetball & tennis courts, a movie theater and more, right there at your workplace?
cons: Base pay (without all the perks mentioned above) is typically lower than industry.  Consider before working here all the possible ramifications of tying your career to your religion.  Each year you will need a new ecclesiastical endorsement from your Bishop - which means you must always be "temple worthy".  What happens if you stop going to church/stop being a full tithe payer/do something that loses you your temple recommend/Really ticks off your Bishop/etc.  You could find yourself being out of a job despite following BYU's honor code and being completely competent and productive in every other way.

review_title: The grass is not always greener on the other side.
pros: Generally people here have the same values as each-other. Benefits are the primary reason to work here. If that is all you want/need then this is the place for you. The family is a priority here and they let you know it. You get to work with some of the brightest people out in the industry.
cons: No advancement. Once you have a job at BYU don't expect moving around a lot. HR is looking for people that are outside of the university. When applying for a new job expect 3 months at the least to land the interview before you are actually hired. The pay is 15% below industry.

job_title: Public Relations Specialist in Provo, UT
pros: I really liked that there was a lot of flexibility.  I basically made my own hours and no one cared as long as I got the work done.  This was a very attractive trait to me of this workplace.  I also thought I was paid well for what my work entailed.  Since I am Mormon, I appreciated the general understanding BYU had of my religious beliefs and respect of my personal religious standards of behavior.
cons: The worst thing about working for BYU is the very conservative work and religious policies.  Sometimes these policies are just plain annoying and hard to work with.  I am a practicing Mormon and believe in my religion, but I still felt very frustrated at times with the policies because I felt like they were somewhat intrusive into my daily life and decisions.  Mainly, it was fear of Honor Code repercussions when I knew I had done nothing wrong.

review_title: This is a wonderful place to work with immaculate grounds, nice buildings, beautiful people, and an uplifting atmosphere
pros: Clean campus, gentle and gracious people, excellent working conditions (in OIT, anyway), and interesting work. The goal of the university - to educate students to go into the world and make it a better place - is supportable and admirable.
cons: Salaries are typically VERY low and employees are expected to consecrate their time and talents to the job with minimal recompense financially. Responsibilities are typically much higher than like positions in industry. For example, I was first hired as a staff employee at half of what industry was paying for a project manager. I was responsible for several million dollars in projects (amounting to nearly twenty active projects). It was crazy. I left to work in industry where I tripled my salary and had my workload reduced to one project that was easily manageable. Then I returned to BYU years later and, because I'd progressed in industry, was hired back as an administrator at 2/3rds of my then current salary but at twice what I was making as a staff employee. You won't get rich working for BYU but it's very secure employment.

review_title: BYU Idaho IT Department is a pretty cool place to work.
pros: It's a great atmosphere to work in because of the employees. They are perfectly willing to work with you when you have a problem. Need to stay home and take care of your sick kid? No problem. Don't know how to do something on the job? They'll help or give you the resources to find out how.
cons: Things are a little rushed. They seem to always be low on head-count budget so the head-count stays under "generally accepted" normal numbers. This means that everyone picks up some extra work and everyone is someone else's backup, even if you don't normally work with their stuff. If they are gone for the day or week then you pick up the slack until they get back. You get to learn a lot of new stuff as a result though.

pros: I have worked with very talented and friendly employers since I've been admitted to the University. The AV department of the OIT building, where I currently work, has excelled in its own field beyond those of many universities like it. The  work environment is both exciting and competitive. The services we provide are both challenging to perform and rewarding to have completed.  I am able to set my own pace, and therefore,  progress rapidly in a variety of unique broadcast skill-sets.
cons: I am an LGBT woman, and often feel unsafe while at work. I remain closeted and silent not only during events,  but also off the clock, for fear of coworkers or employers finding out. I have anonymously reported harassment to my supervisors about some of my coworkers.

job_title: BYU Delivery Driver in Provo, UT
pros: Environment is pleasant. Everyone you work with are fairly kind and respectful, and a fair working atmosphere is emphasised. The pay is set low, and raises are minimal, but they exist! Fairly simple work with a lot of opportunity to work on homework while still performing. Hours are flexible depending on classes.
cons: BYU bureaucracy is ridiculous. It's a "grunt work for students" situation, and the people on top make it extremely difficult for any student who wants to do a really job actually be able to. It's hard to jump through the hoops. Hours may be flexible, but there are hardly any raises, so there is super high turnover in every department while all students are trying to find the best paying job. The departments all have separate rules and agendas.

job_title: Student Web Developer in Provo, UT

cons: Very limited resources for learning and real-world experience. Very stressful environment. School is supposedly a priority unless a deadline is looming. Applications and web sites are full of holes and are poorly developed due to lack of experience and knowledge.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Provo, UT
pros:
BYU is full of kind, excellent people who are, more often than not, willing to provide their expertise to help you accomplish your goals. The culture is wholesome and respectful. Research positions provide large amounts of flexibility, allowing you to set your hours how you want and often direct your own work how you want.

Research here provides really cool opportunities to do work on the cutting edge. Student researchers get hands-on opportunities to create amazing, cutting edge technology. Often faculty share the credit. There is nearly no infighting, almost everyone wants to support each other in their work.
cons: Student research assistant pay is usually not far above minimum wage. Bureaucracy surrounding risk often creates excessive hoops, and sometimes barriers, to innovation. Risk management tends to impede great work entirely instead of facilitating it's safe fulfillment.

pros:
The people are great to work with. You have to have a good sense of humor or you don't stay. 
Working with a different client each day. Becaus you are catering the people you work with changes daily and so does the event and event type. 
Learning many skills that help with other jobs. You learn so many transferable skills. How to work with all kinds of people do to the diversity at campus, also how to think quickly on your feet.
cons:
Long hours with so-so compenation. It is a student job and in hospitality. So the pay isn't the best and you can be working long hours at random times. It is also an on call job so some weeks you don't work and others you work too much
High rate of overturn. Because it is students, there is a high percentage new people needing to be taught on the job all the time.

pros: They allowed me to work at my own pace. I was given a list of things to do, and I completed them when needed. I just had to ask if I ever needed more work. They are very supportive of the work you complete, complimenting when a job is well done. This position provided a lot of skills and opportunities for me to work on my skills while in school. The people are very friendly, including the professors and administrators.
cons: Sometimes you are given small, ridiculous projects--like printing papers for a supervisor. Many of the people in the college are older and set in their ways. At times it was difficult for them to understand new fads, concepts, or technology. They think they know what looks or is best, but they don't.

review_title: Plenty of opportunities to learn and excel
pros:
I have held various positions as a student at BYU, working in Facilities, Risk Management, and as a Departmental Teacher Assistant for two different courses. Throughout all of my experiences, I have found that my managers have been very respectful of my time and responsibilities at school, which has lead to a very balanced work/school dynamic. 

Responsibilities at work vary greatly depending on your role, but integrity and quality of work is an expectation throughout the workplace. My positions have given me ample opportunity to grow and to learn alongside my studies.
cons: Paid compensation is overall mediocre. Expectations for delivered work and pay are not equally balanced. Many students seek secondary jobs off-campus, or even avoid campus employment altogether because of low on-campus pay.

pros: BYU has great benefits and they are very flexible with schedules.  They have a great atmosphere.  There are good opportunities for growth and training.
cons: Many positions at BYU are very stagnant when it comes to job promotions.  You get a 2-4% cost of living raise each year, but it is very hard to get any other sort of monetary advancement.

job_title: IT Engineer III in Provo, UT
pros: Stable work environment, pretty good benefits, education encouraged and paid for by the University. The University also allows for educational benefits for spouse and children. BYU is also a very clean, moral work environment that encourages people to "play nicely". Benefits include a good 401K program, a pension, good medical insurance, a Wellness program that encourages healthy living.
cons: LOTS of politics, too many decisions are made and maintained emotionally. The dental insurance leaves a lot to be desired and the medical insurance, while pretty good, is continually increasing in cost. One of the biggest problems is the management that have been at the help TOOO long and try to maintain things as they have always been instead of recognizing the need for change.

pros: Good people. Strong organizational mission. I really enjoyed working with all my colleagues there. I love working with students and I learned a lot.
cons:
Training is boring, but I'm not sure that it's any more boring than any other place. Sometimes it seems that some departments are very liberal with the funding they receive for some of their projects, on the other hand, they have pretty limited budgets, so they make sure they use every penny.

Most of my student co-workers are just passing the time there. Maybe that's part of the mission, to give students token jobs as opposed to actually getting productive use out of them.

review_title: Decent as a student, would never do it as a professional.
pros: Flexible schedule while in school, easy jobs to get once you are qualified to be a teaching assistant for a class you've taken before.
cons: Ridiculous amount of rules and regulations and the inability to clock in from home when working from home for a significant amount of time. If I could've clocked in from home and clocked out from home, it would've been much simpler. (This is referring to being a TA, where grading 20 hours worth of assignments over a weekend was not uncommon at all).

review_title: Good experience overall but not super exciting in either of my jobs; Food was first job, then research job
pros:
-Easy to get any job on campus
-Meet some fun friends. In both of my jobs I met great people who were there to have a good time and enjoy the college experience. Some even aspired for a lot of good things in their futures
-Good to get started on working
-Research job was very flexible with time and balance of family/work.
cons:
-Both jobs were boring at times. 
-Management in the food job was not the best. They were never there. Management in the research was great except for the sense of direction and vision were pretty fuzzy. 
-Time isn't flexible in the food job.

review_title: Happiest I've ever been working for an employer.
pros:
Extremely positive, friendly, and clean work environment. I have never been happier at any job. BYU provides an excellent benefits package which includes a pension and 401k; great medical, dental, disability, group term life (GTL), etc... They also provide tuition benefits for employees and their families, as well as other benefits, perks, and discounts associated with the University.

The real value of BYU employment is the satisfaction in carrying out the mission of the University. Employees are very close to the fruits of their labors, and receive great fulfillment in their work. This in turn helps invigorate me to work better and harder for BYU. And I feel very appreciated for what I do because I see the difference my work makes in the lives of individuals and the community.
cons: A low employee turnover renders difficulty in obtaining employment at BYU.

job_title: Mechanical Engineering TA in Provo, UT
pros: Working with the students (the ones I was teaching) was a great experience. They were happy to receive my help. They students all live up to BYU standards, so everyone was easy to deal with.
cons: Pay was low for a Mechanical Engineer. The TA's can always use more training in how to help the students. The TA's (fellow coworkers) need to be more proactive in helping the students learn and in addressing their needs. They too often sit at their desk on their phones or computer and wait for the students to approach them for help. This is not accommodating to the quiet students who are usually the ones who fall behind.

job_title: Physics Demonstration Coordinator in Provo, UT
pros: BYU has a great environment where most of the time people really care about your success and happiness. They provide all full time employee with a great benefits package. They take the needs of the students very seriously. Students' comments about the quality of their experience at BYU is taken very seriously.
cons: Sometimes because student opinions about their experience in a class are taken so seriously a complaining student often get more results from complaining that from hard work and following the expectations of the faculty. As with any large organization it is often difficult to find the person that you need to help you solve a problem.

review_title: Great job if you like cold winters
pros: Great people, Beautiful place, great opportunities. If you are familiar with the teachings of latter-day saints this job will be more enjoyable. There are great benefits to having a job at the university. If you have a child attempting to get into school, their chances are significantly greater. There are also significant discounts to all sporting events f you're into that kind of thing.
cons: Small town, not a lot to do. The city is over run with college students from other states from september to april. There aren't many families that are permanent residents of the town, so the city council has many students trying to build their career not attempting to help the city. There are very cold winters. Many people from the same demographic. Not much Diversity.

review_title: Helps with course development, teaching, grading.  Also presents information to students on a regular basis.
pros: Great exposure to new ideas and prestige of working for an educational institution that's one of the best in the world.  It also makes it easier to work in an environment where ethics and character are not only important, but fundamental.
cons: As with any  other job in the education world, pay is comparably less than equivalent jobs in the private sector.

review_title: BYU is a good place for an education.
pros: I am overall neutral in that I am a PhD student and don't plan on being employed by BYU for a long term job.  It is a wonderful environment  to receive and education. The faculty and staff treat you well.  As a research assistant there are many opportunities to learn and develop new skills.   There really isn't much room for progression in this job but that is expected in that all research assistants are students and aren't making a career out of their current positions.  There is plenty of room for progression in that we publish a lot and make other advancements that help our resume for the future.
cons: It is always nice to get paid more but we are students so there isn't much to complain about.

review_title: a part time student worker's point of view at BYU
job_title: Career and Major Advisor in Provo, UT
pros: Part of why I do the work I do is that it is good for my resume for the future.  The employees that I work with are friendly and easy to get along with. The students at BYU are great to work with, highly intelligent and willing to take advise and guidence nad work to do better in life.
cons: BYU tends to be very myopic in their view of how they can help the students.  Individuals have been in their positions for years and do not want to leave but also are so comfortable they are not about ot change how they currently go about their work.

review_title: Great place to work and learn
pros: Colleagues were a pleasure to work with. Supervisor was very accommodating, and very willing to help employees with any questions we had. We were included in conversations with senior staff about how to fulfill the needs of our patrons. The work was fulfilling, and we received proper training to excel at it.
cons: I loved the job. During less busy times, though, it was occasionally easy to get complacent. While I appreciated the occasional less-stressful period, I probably could have done more in those less busy times to explore resources I was less familiar with. More direction on how to make the most of less busy times may have been helpful.

pros: Able to increase your own given knowledge of your taken math courses. As well as able to help those in need of better understanding of the giving subjects. Very rewarding to see others grasp the  material that you are trying to teach. Also very relaxed with hours. They will work with your schedule and allows you to work as many hours up to 20 and as few as you like. Great job for such a small town with such a high demand for jobs.
cons: Job can be mentally demanding after a long day of study. Well be required to teach much of the same material over many times, can get a little repetitive.

review_title: Big turn over rate, but I worked with some really quality individuals. Would recommend it to any one there.
pros: We worked in an environment of other LDS students that had similar standards as me. A lot of the managers there are really fun and take the time to get to know who works for them.
cons: Several of the non student personnel treated students like they were inferior or dumb. There really wasn't any chance for advancement. You kind of get stuck at one salary and it usually doesn't matter how long you work there, you aren't moving up.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Provo, UT
pros: As a graduate research assistant, you feel like you belong and, depending on your faculty advisor, you are treated on par with staff and even faculty in research decisions and some decisions affecting the direction of the department. The environment is amazing. Working on a beautiful campus with outstanding professionals is what brought me here in the first place.
cons: BYU places most of its emphasis on undergraduate opportunities and, as a result, resources and class priorities are shifted in that direction. This hasn't been a deterrent for myself, although it is definitely a factor.

pros: The environment here is great--if you are a faculty member.  A lot of people tend to be happy.
cons: Student employees are treated very poorly.  Immediate supervisors are often effective, but deans do not usually care.  Unfortunately, staff are treated as second class citizens.  I understand that there may need to be some differing levels of organization, but all people should be treated with respect.  Also, faculty members are underpaid.  Starting salaries are great, but their is almost no chance for them to receive pay raises.  Some faculty members have even reported to me that they have taken pay cuts when promoted.

pros: One Stop Student Services is a great place to meet new people and really feel like you belong to a cohort of students. You work with the same 20 people for your three-hour shift every single day.
cons: Trying customers, management has their hands tied on most issues because of the administration of BYU, once you know the information the job can become extremely boring, the hours are not flexible and this is not a student-friendly job.

review_title: Computer Support Specialist at the Office of Information Technology (OIT)
job_title: Computer Support Specialist in Provo, UT
pros: Great work environment, great co-workers. Clients and co-workers are generally nice and pleasant to work with. OIT pays well compared to other student jobs. My immediate supervisors were very good. Overall I enjoyed the experience. Working on campus is very convenient.
cons: OIT goes through frequent transitions, which made it difficult to find the right employee for various services. They have a bad reputation on campus and many people don't like dealing with them. Although it pays well compared to other student jobs you can generally make more money working off campus. It seems that because they don't pay the full-time employees competitively, they don't necessarily attract top talent.

job_title: Computer Specialist II in Provo, UT
pros: Great benefits. Very very stable employment. Very safe workplace.
cons: Depending on the department, legacy IT applications are extremely antiquated and it is extremely difficult to get anyone, including lower and upper management to move off old systems on to newer, much more improved technology that would vastly improve situation.

pros: I was able to work part-time as a student at the university with flexible hours. The people I worked with were generally nice. There was not a lot to do sometimes but nobody seemed to care enough to reprimand anyone.
cons: It is difficult to work with other people on campus. It is not because they are mean or incompetent. Hawaii is a very relaxed culture, and nobody is in too much of a rush to do task quickly. I would often speak with other departments on the phone and I would have to wait a day or two to speak with a person on the phone, or I would have to go find them myself. Other than a lot of times with not much to do, that was the only bad thing.

pros: BYU is willing to work with your class schedule and help you to succeed in any position, they reward longevity. Great to work with students and faculty alike who share relatively the same values and standards that you do.
cons: Won't allow you to go over 20 hours a week if you're a student, unless you work over the summer. Longevity is preferred, and may hurt you financially (ie - you don't get your 6 month raise if you're planning on leaving after seven months of working there).

review_title: Good place to work while in college.
pros: The people you work with are good, happy, and helpful.  The atmosphere is clean, friendly, and not too stressful.  Coworkers and supervisors are perfectly happy to help and show you the ropes and roles as a job.  They are willing to work with class schedules so it is possible to work and go to school.
cons: As a student employee there is a cap to what you can do and the type of promotions you can get.  Pay doesn't really seem to increase much for accomplishments in some departments and does in others.  So you may or may not be compensated.

review_title: My work here is rewarding and I plan on continuing here for the duration of my tenure as a graduate student.
pros: Very clean environment and professors are usually willing to help. The workload is not usually super high and you can find time to do your classwork. The class offerings are at least relatively good, so you usually can find a topic to focus on and study.
cons: The culture can be sort of odd to outsiders. If you are not LDS, coming here will be a foreign experience. Office space is a bit cramped and some duties (such as teaching Calc 2) can be very time consuming. There is at timesa feeling of being really rushed to get the degree, since BYU wants to get rid of you as fast as they possibly can.

pros: Flexible schedule, and great work environment. Bosses are very helpful and understanding of students' responsibilities. I have learned useful skills to take with me as I leave BYU.
cons: The only downside of working at my current job is that while I have flexibility on my hours and shifts, I am only able to work weekdays from 8am - 5pm. Nights and weekends are not available which is nice, but all my classes are during the week and it makes it hard to get 20 hours in.

pros: I enjoyed my time working for BYU, and attending as a student. Great place to get an education! Overall, I liked working in a purpose driven environment, with highly motivated colleagues.
cons: The main reason for the poor rating is simply to call attention to the irony that BYU (an institution which supports strong family values), has a very lack luster approach to its parental leave policies. Nothing beyond the statutory requirements of the law is offered. No paid time off for mothers or fathers (unless they use their vacation days).  I expect more from an institution of this caliber and mission.

review_title: Great place to work as a student
job_title: Student Web Developer in Provo, UT
pros: Great environment to work in, there are lots of different types of jobs to choose from with a wide-range of salaries.  Many of the jobs are flexible allowing students to work around their class schedules to be able to get their hours every week.  Depending on the job, you can typically get raises once a semester or a larger amount once a year.  The experience most student jobs provides better opportunities for future employment options
cons: The only downside is that you can often find better paying jobs off-campus but that is because it is so convenient to work on campus that they can pay a little less.  Raises may not always be as great as one would hope or come as often.

pros: The team I worked with was awesome. My boss is one of the best guys I've ever worked with. The environment was great, and even though I was a student employee I was given a voice and a real chance to contribute to the projects I worked on.
cons: There seemed to be a lot of bureaucracy and red tape that made working on certain projects difficult. The organizations and people requesting projects from us often were not clear with their requests and would change things on a whim, even if it wasn't in their best interest to do so.

pros: It's an excellent environment no smoking, no drinking.  Since it is a university, the atmosphere is not stressful.  Other employees are nice.  The benefits are great.  The campus is very clean.  Since it is a associated with the Mormon church, there is a balance between family and work.
cons: The pay isn't that great a bit below scale.  In my opinion, which is obviously biased, I should be making at least $10,000 more a year.  Additionally, there is no system in place to reward doing an above average job.  No bonuses.  And the Christmas present is a book.  I wish they would give us cash.

review_title: BYU, Marriott School great place to work.
pros: The Marriott School of Management, in particular, fosters a lot of innovation and creativity. Programs with high potential can get a lot of good support. Having students as resources as well as the product being created forms a nice synergy, because students will work hard for you and become better job candidates as a result. The current Dean is wise, generous, and attentive.
cons: The pressures to hire academics can limit the opportunities for valuable, professional part-time faculty to move into more permanent positions. Sometimes one feels like some university administrators feel entitled to act like General Authorities in approaching their decision-making, and will not counsel well with those affected as a result.

job_title: Finance Major Office Manager in Provo, UT
pros: Hard work is rewarded with raises fairly often (in the Marriott School anyway, because of more sponsors), the school is family oriented, and the Finance professors are typically competitive but "normal" people.
cons: The department can be very political at times. Student workers can also be reprimanded if they do anything anyone complains about, even if the student worker did nothing wrong. Some in the department are too afraid to offend anyone.  I was reprimanded for trying to use Google Docs because another adult employee didn't want to learn how to use the program or a computer.

job_title: BYU Computer Science Teaching Assistant in Provo, UT
pros: Incredible freedom on how you can use your time. TA hours are often underutilized, so a surprisingly high percentage of the time, you can do homework or something else during working hours. It is very convenient to work in the same building that CS classes are in at times you get to choose.
cons: Little to no training on how to use Learning Suite as a TA.  Learning Suit itself is a mediocre system for doing things like entering grades, changing assignments, etc. Compensation for higher level CS TAs is less than what could be obtained elsewhere..

pros: For pros, I could set my own schedule while studying as a student. It was one of the higher paying jobs available to me as a student.
cons:
The pay was never enough to survive on, even with all tuition covered by scholarships and after a slight pay raise of $0.25 after a year of employment.
I never felt connected to opportunities to grow or expand my horizons despite working diligently and producing high-quality results.

review_title: Dining Services-Good job opportunities, need new upper management
job_title: Food Production Specialist- Food to Go in Provo, UT
pros: It is very easy to get a job in dining services and there are always positions. Generally it is a low stress job that works well with class hours, homework, and social life. Lower managers seem down to earth and understand the life of a student.
cons: Low pay. That is pretty much found at all of the non-technical university jobs. Upper management is stale and lacks vision. They seem like they couldn't care less about the students and sometimes the lower management as well. Most are just sticking around for their retirement package. Give it to them early and get some younger people in there.

pros: Great benefits, facilities, hr training/development, sports programs, beautiful campus, AMAZING student employees who do great work.
cons: Higher ed: at times you get this feeling that this quote really is true, "politics of higher ed are the worst kind because the stakes are so low." Implement a little or low tolerance for checking social networking sites while on the job.

review_title: A great place to work if you have the right boss.
job_title: Computer Support Representative in Provo, UT
pros: Working part-time for BYU may include a very flexible schedule and can be very rewarding depending on your boss.  The work environment is mostly positive and friendly.
cons: Working part-time for BYU means no benefits and a lot of hard work to be noticed when looking for a promotion.  The hiring process can be very cumbersome if working for two different departments of BYU either concurrently or successively.

pros: This is a job that helps while a person is in school.  Each position is on campus and helps a person to become more efficient in their planning because the zero travel time.  They understand why you are working there, and want to help out...sometimes certain positions are basically paying you to study.
cons: Everybody is looking for a job.  So if you dont want to be paid minimum wage, someone else will be more than willing to do so.  Also, everybody thinks that they know everything under the sun.  This is a place for education and so those teaching need to act as if they know everything

pros: This job is good for students as it offers a fairly higher starting pay than other campus jobs as far as I know. The schedule is flexible around school classes and it is still easy to get up to 20 hours usually either scheduled or by picking up other people's shifts. Good work environment and crew. Definitely recommend it.
cons: Sometimes the hours can be inconvenient if you have a 4am shift or work friday/saturday nights. The library needs security on Sundays as well. Typically you only work those shifts if you want to but if no one  takes them then people need to take their turn and sometimes you got to do it. Other than that no cons pretty much.

review_title: It was an international experience with an education benefit outweighing the cost and real training in chosen career.
job_title: Junior Accountant- Accounts Payable in Laie, HI
pros: If you would like to be involved in the education experience and see the influence of your teaching span the globe through students you influence in your classes and jobs than this would be the place for you to work.
cons: The pay is less since you are working for a private university as well as the school is currently undergoing major expansion projects that are currently requiring many changes in departmental leadership and additions to faculty.

review_title: Exceptional education and exceptional work opportunities
pros: Brigham Young University always provides excellent opportunities for their students to grow and learn from high-quality instructors. Doing research with these professors provides great opportunities for students to begin to work in their field of interest and the opportunities look great on applications and resumes. They respect their students and inspire them to achieve excellence and lifelong service and learning.
cons: There are honestly so many great things about working at Brigham Young University. I would say the only thing I could think of is just educating their students on the opportunities that are available to them.

review_title: BYU is a great place to work only if you don't need much money.
pros:
Very close to classes and my apartment.
Management gives good feedback on the work done.
The people are great to work with.
There is always somebody there to help if get stuck, and there isn't any criticism that I've come across.
There are a lot of opportunities for time off.  Manangement understands how school can be very hard one week, so they will let you off for some hours in a week.
cons:
Pay is very low.
Jobs are very basic, so sometimes the tasks are mundane.
They don't offer any benefits if you are a student. 
There isn't a whole lot of career opportunity in advancement.

review_title: Computer Help Desk Representative (aka best job on campus)
job_title: Computer Help Desk Representative in Rexburg, ID
pros: Works around student schedule.  Pretty lenient in allowing to take time off for personal reason.  Steep learning curve but evens out over time.  Employees are willing to help answer questions that you don't know the answer to.
cons: When they are hiring and you are off track you need to make sure that you ensure your job when you are coming back or you could be out of luck.  That happened to me and I missed out one semester.

review_title: 4 years of growth and productive enjoyment
job_title: Computer Support Representative in Provo, UT
pros: Very professional, things kept improving year by year. As a private university, the school has a ton more "say" in how they use their funds, and I am happy with how they treat employees. I was fairly compensated and given every opportunity to succeed.
cons: I think the "honor code" can be taken too far. For example, to work at the Department of Religion, I was not allowed to wear flip-flops or shorts. That seems a bit paternalistic.

review_title: BYU Creamery on Ninth East PT: Enjoyable Receiving/Stocking and Grocery (Cashier)
job_title: A M Grocery Supervisor/Manager in Provo, UT
pros:
-The managers understand that school responsibilities come first.
-Many friendly people.
-Enjoyable work for students (up to about 20 hours per week).
-Some potential for promotion to supervisor or manager; good leadership experience.
-Delicious food everywhere.
-Respect from management.
cons:
-Some co-workers may put in less effort than desirable, sometimes when there is still much to be done.
-Emotions may rage in the early morning or in the late evening for some employees (not on a regular basis).
-Some areas may be rather filthy by the time the early morning shift arrives; the morning custodian often has his/her work cut out.

review_title: Working on campus was perfect while I went to school.
pros: I received a pay increase once or twice a year, scheduling time off wasn't too hard, so nice to be able to go straight from class to work without traveling too far. The staff in the office I worked in was great (Student Records and Registration). I gained experience in training, interviewing, hiring, customer service and many other skills. I have some great references from this job and built lifelong friendships here. I recommend working on campus to any student.
cons: Some full time employees on campus don't take student employees seriously, but for the most part they are ok. I recommend working on campus to any student.

pros: It's a wonderful environment, and the co-workers and managers are awesome! It's highly satisfying, and I would totally recommend this to anyone who has done well in math classes at BYU. The more semesters you work, the better the pay. The students are very respectful, and are good learners, so it's fun to work with them. They even train you to become a certified teaching assistant, which looks great on a resume. They're very thoughtful and organized, and you feel like a part of a family.
cons: It doesn't pay very much, and I needed to find a job that pays more.

review_title: Great place to work for students.
pros: BYU is a good place to work, especially for students. They are always very flexible. Full time workers have very good benefits.
cons: Sometimes there are funny politics that BYU runs by. Often times we would have restrictions placed on us without any explanation for the restrictions. Some of the management doesn't get to know their subordinates. It is, however, difficult to assign this review to the whole organization of BYU because it is so large. That being said, the IT department does have silly politics. Communication between the different areas of IT is not great, but we all get our work done.

review_title: Great job for students who want to gain relevant experience
pros: I was able to work with a number of professors and professionals who are serious about their work and are committed to excellence.  I was seen as a critical part of the operations within the department and was trusted with significant duties that helped me gain a greater knowledge of how to work with others and how to use my strengths to make an impact.
cons: There really are no "cons" to this job.

review_title: Typically good people, nice environment, good benefits, mediocre salary.
pros: Working at BYU is nice because people are generally nice and clean-spoken (it's a requirement, as a matter of fact). The benefits are pretty good too, and there are lots of outdoor activities in the area.
cons:
There isn't much room for rapid growth or movement in the university, and most people stick around until they retire (fine for them, bad for you if you want a different job). Salary is on the bottom edge of what I'd consider appropriate for the job/skills.

Can't grow a beard.
Outdated dress code -- can't wear shorts or sandals... even if you're an IT guy who doesn't interface with customers.

job_title: Special Projects Coordinator in Provo, UT
pros: The people are great. When I was not able to drive for health reasons, My coworkers gave me rides to and from work for three months. They also supported a coworker in her fight with cancer by donating vacation days to her sick leave. There are tons of opportunities for personal growth, it is easy to get time off when you need it. The environment is uplifting.
cons:
Cons...cons. People stay for years and years so it's hard to get a job here. 
If you are really concerned about money you wouldn't want to work here. But I guess that's also kind of a pro, because the people who work here aren't concerned about the money.

pros: I have one of the higher-paying jobs on campus and I really enjoy it. They are very considerate of my school schedule and most everyone is a joy to be around. I love my job.
cons:
The pay is very low. I understand why, especially since none of us are professionals yet, but I am very good at my job, and I would appreciate being paid accordingly.
Also, BYU has a policy that full-time students are not allowed to work more than 20 hours per week on campus. Again I understand why, but not everyone is in the same situation; some students might need/want more hours.

pros: University benefits including retirement, salary, vacation, sick, health, and everything else is pretty great. Religious environment is great for those that are LDS.
cons: Management is pretty terrible in certain areas. Very odd decisions being made all the time. Every building on campus is it's own silo with little collaboration around the University.

pros:

pros:
If you're offered a TA job, TAKE IT! Being a TA offers financial, professional and academical benefits in ways other college jobs don't.

The professors I assisted (two at a time, sometimes) were generous in each allowing the maximum number of hours per week AND letting me set my own office hours. Because my employers were familiar with my schedule and the academic calendar, maintaining a work/school/life balance was easier than if I'd worked off-campus, and the hourly wage was much higher than the minimum wage I'd be earning anywhere else. 

Because I was assisting in an academic area I hoped to pursue in my graduate education, getting to know my professors better by working for them allowed for stronger letters of recommendation. I was also able to have more frequent out-of-classroom conversations with them about my research.

I learned great things about writing from correcting hundreds (and hundreds, and hundreds) of other students' essays. And because the classes I assisted were related to classes I'd taken in the past--but not necessarily identical--I was able to learn new things without the burden of paying extra tuition or doing unpaid homework. Plus, if you schedule the maximum number of office hours, chances are pretty good that *most* of the time students won't be coming to visit you (except leading up to a test or major assignment). Once you've finished any of the grading/prep the professors assigns, you can totally do your own homework during the remaining office hours. Sweet!
cons:
Make sure your professor is okay with you setting your own boundaries with students. Otherwise, dealing with procrastinators can be really difficult--expect to see a good dozen kids in your office the day before a major assignment is due, each wanting you to line-edit their draft (or help them write an initial outline). You totally want to help, but there's not a lot you can do at that point. And don't make the mistake of allowing students to email you their drafts for feedback right up until the day before deadline--I must have given feedback on a good hundred essays in a single day trying to fulfil the committment I'd made.
Additionally, student athletes can be remarkably entitled (not all, but some--I've never had a non-student athlete assume none of the rules apply to them). In one of my larger classes I had several swim team and baseball team members. The swim students came in regularly and early for help with their essays and test study groups. When they knew they'd be away from campus for an exam or assignment, they were careful to complete it early. The baseball team members regularly missed exams without notice, turned in papers late, and then expected us to accommodate them by changing the syllabus rules since they were student athletes. (? It's college. You're here to learn.) The swim team students passed with flying colors. The baseball team students failed.

review_title: BYU is a great place for Latter-day Saints to work.  Family friendly, with incredible benefits.
pros: While a lot of people say the pay is mediocre, I've found in my particular line of work the pay in line with or slightly better than other colleges and universities around the country.  The people are excellent, most of the students are respectful and engaged in their education, most of the student employees are responsible and enthusiastic.  My peers and managers are all thoughtful in their duties, aware of how their decisions impact those around them, and timely in getting things done.  There are tons of resources around campus to use professionally and personally.  Benefits include health insurance (with vision and dental options), retirement savings plan, pension, tuition, access to facilities and resources.  They are generous in their employer contributions to insurance and retirement plans.
cons: The administration can be resistant to change that comes from the ground up.  Often, big decisions/changes to policy are made without consulting the employees or stakeholders who will be most impacted by those changes.  There is a culture of enduring the few employees who under-perform; issues typically drag on for years before a supervisor is fed up enough to take any action, which can frustrate those who work with under-performers.  The university's official stance is they do not believe in comping time.  If you have a salaried position that requires periodic work after hours or on weekends--even several nights and weekends per month--it has no impact on your need to be there from 8 to 5 during the week.  A number of departments are top-heavy on administration, with little upward mobility.
