The basic idea at MFPC is to help people with their computers, so keep that in mind when talking to people and if they don't want or need your help, wish them a good day and move on.
cons:
Though all sales positions are part time (at least while I was there), I recommend against being heavily involved in something else outside of MFPC while working in sales. I tried to be a full-time university student at the same time and it didn't take long to see that one of them had to go, unfortunately in my situation it was the job.

A lot of meetings! Seemed like we were always in a meeting and I often felt like they did not apply to me.

Also, my team had some issues with unprofessional work conduct including the manager, but I believe the responsible parties were either terminated or demoted and retrained shortly after I left.

Last but especially not least: for those with some sales experience, you will notice a misalignment in the sales management at MFPC. They claim to be an outcome-oriented company, but the management is definitely skewed toward a behavior-oriented system.

pros:
Very friendly and supportive colleagues and environment. Extremely family friendly -- supervisors wanted to make sure your family life was well taken care of before work priorities.

Talented and eager student employees. In my office there was a 50/50 male/female ratio which was a great dynamic. Great gym facilities; healthcare and retirement benefits were amazing.
cons: A relative lack of diversity, which wasn't necessarily a bad thing--somewhat the nature of the beast being in Idaho, but the campus was much more diverse than some folks make it out to be. The community and surrounding region was somewhat less diverse.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Provo, UT
pros: Great on-campus part time work for a student. Paid well (for a campus job) for doing interesting research. Work is self-motivated and it's great to see your work pay off when a paper gets published. Work under awesome professors. Had great lab parties.
cons: For a while my research lab was unsure of its funding which makes it hard to know if I will have a job in the future or not.

pros:
-Easy job
-easy to pick up new hours and get your shifts covered
-shifts tend to work well around a schedule (a shift will only be 2.5 hours long, max)
-Pay is above Idaho minimum wage ($8.50)
-Fun environment to work in
-Things are VERY lax (this can be a downside too), so you can be a minute late to work, and possibly leave at any time if you need to and it's not busy.

This is an excellent student job. I've worked at other places such as Broulims, SSI, and applied to a million others. this one requires very little energy, so it leaves you more oomph for the rest of your day. If you like being challenged, then this might not be for you. You can make the testing center a better place, but there are limited options for movement upward. they are all based on chance.
cons:
-Poor management and leadership (both the student leadership, and the full-time staff)
-Student coworkers most of the time could care less about their job, so you'll have to pick up the slack for them if you're a decent person.
-You work with other students on a daily basis, so prepare to be recognizable around campus
-Dress code is pretty strict for a barely-above minimum wage job. 
-You will be required to enforce the honor code, regardless if you agree with it or not. That includes pulling students aside to remind them to follow the dress code.
-The administrators are unnecessarily strict about silly things. If you make mistakes, prepare to be called out for it, and be called out much worse than one would expect. I would make tiny mistakes, and be pulled into the office and lectured for several minutes.

pros: It's so nice to go from class to work to class and not have to waste travel time going somewhere else. I don't know about all student jobs, but I have loved mine (OIT). They make sure you put school first, freedom to make changes, great experience, etc. etc.
cons: Could use a little more trust from engineers.

pros:
-Considering the local cost of living, the graduate stipend is quite good compared to similar universities
-Advisors care more about the students than their research careers
cons: The university has an adequate reputation for future employment opportunities, but isn't a top 10 school by any means. I don't think this reasonably constitutes a con however. Other than that, grad school pros and cons are mostly about the student and the advisor, not the school.

review_title: Assist commercial interior designer with space planning, computer modeling, meeting with clients and project management.
job_title: Assistant Interior Designer in Provo, UT
pros: Good people, wonderful environment. The schedule is very flexible. I've learned so much! It is a great student job for people during their time at BYU. It is amazing to see the behind the scenes of physical facilities. I am able to coordinate with other professionals and complete projects for beautiful, functional design.
cons: There is some workplace drama with a lack of respect for interior design amongst all the other shops and trades. Interior design could use some more space in the office.

review_title: A remarkable place to work and contribute to a noteworthy cause. "Enter to learn, go forth to serve."
job_title: Office of Information Technology in Provo, UT
pros: A values based organization sponsored by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Employees generally believe in the cause and are interested in its fulfillment. To "assist individuals in their pursuit of perfection and eternal life."
cons: Given the lofty goal of the stated mission, and the reality of the "human element" in the daily work environment it can be a ripe environment for unintended passive aggressive behavior.

job_title: Student Computer Programmer in Provo, UT
pros:
I was provided plenty of opportunities to learn on the job, even though I was only a part-time employee.  Seminars and workshops are frequently held at BYU and my manager encouraged me to go when possible.

I am currently a student and BYU OIT flexible with my schedule in both jobs that I held there.
cons: The project I was assigned to used older technologies than I would have preferred to work on.  Even so, I was able to learn a lot about general programming practices that I'e been able to apply elsewhere.

pros: Amazing instructor. Nearly zero experience needed besides taking the class beforehand. Flexible hours and the opportunity to meet many people and learn new things every semester. Also provided quite a bit of experience with intrapersonal relationships and teaching and creating assignments and other required documents.
cons: Very few other than sometimes grading can be dull. You also have to deal with student complaints for various things.

pros: Flexible work schedule, great environment, good opportunities for advancement, opportunities to learn new skills to aid you in future careers
cons: My office has no AC so the summer can be rather miserable at time. Getting a parking place can be difficult if you are not there first thing in the morning.

review_title: Great opportunity for learning with minimal pay.
pros: Honest environment, great friends, and wonderful research program.  BYU is a great place to rub shoulders with some of the best people in academia. Tuition is cheap if you are a student.
cons: Low pay for research assistants.  Not much to live on, but helps you get by.  Unfortunately, being a research assistant is not a good example of how working for BYU really is.

pros: Fantastic & beautiful clean, well-kept campus. Outstandingly generous benefits package, both health and retirement benefits. Great people, great community feel. Almost every person I work with or have help me with an issue is very helpful and efficient. Runs like a well-oiled machine.
cons: Lower salaries than compared to the market, but is certainly made up for in generous offering of benefits.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant (Computer Science) in Provo, UT
pros:
Your lead TA will generally make the difference; mine is fantastic, so I enjoy it!
The hours are flexible; if you need time off, just get someone else to cover your shift (usually very easy).
There are meetings every week and the teachers listen to you and your recommendations. 
Because this school is LDS-affiliated, they do not want you to work on Sundays; therefore, you are guaranteed every Sunday off.
cons: This completely depends on your department. I am a TA for the Computer Science department, and I absolutely love it.

pros: I LOVE LOVE LOVE my supervisor. He understands I'm a busy student and he lets me adjust my hours accordingly. I've enjoyed being with BYU grounds because the hours are generally earlier in the day, leaving my evenings free for socialization or homework. I like to say that at BYU grounds, we work hard and we play hard.
cons:
There's a limit on the number of hours that you can work during the school year.
Sometimes we're at the whim of our supervisor's boss who doesn't always understand what our tasks are, but then again, who isn't?

review_title: Great work experience. Boasts more student employees than most Universities but average pay.
pros: I worked for Freshman Academy (Now Freshman Mentoring. The work was very fulfilling. Helping freshmen connect to university resources, faculty, and each other was hard work but at the end of the day I felt great about what I was doing.
cons:
Pay is average unless you are doing something like computer programming. So for janitorial, secretarial, or other type entry level work you're looking somewhere below $10/hr. 
The MTC although not technically BYU has very competitive payscale and offers a very positive work environment.

review_title: Was a research assistant and had an amazing time and learned a lot!
pros: So much fun! A great environment. The professor was amazing to work with. I learned so much doing research with the psychology team! The grad students were awesome as well. It was great to see some of the amazing research that is going on at BYU and to be a part of it!
cons: The compensation was pretty good. There isn't really any room for promotions because the graduate students are usually the ones running the show, but as an undergrad you expect that.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Provo, UT
pros:
Clean workplace with high standards including honest living and willingness of professor to engage researcher in their own research interests. 
High quality learning experience with training in professional skills.
cons:
Bachelor's degree seemed to fly by too quickly as I was engaged in learning and professional advancement/training.
I was required to limit my work hours to 20 due to going to school full time.

review_title: Flexible, Caring, Honest, People-Oriented, Friendly Place to Work
job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Provo, UT
pros: The best part about working for BYU is how kind and caring everyone is. No one has a "what can I do to just get my paycheck and get out" attitude; rather, people genuinely want to help others' days go better.
cons: The pay as a part-time employee could be better. There are very few pay levels for part-time student employees, so even though I have a lot to do at work that requires specific skills and training, I make the same as the people who do one task.

job_title: Public Relations Coordinator in Provo, UT
pros:
- I learned a lot about industry expectations in this position. 
 - Because of this experience, I feel comfortable giving presentations and proposing ideas in a formal business meeting setting. 
 - My management skills improved while working here.
 - This office is very goals oriented, specifically SMART goals, which I now feel like I accurately understand how to formulate and implement.
cons: - Intense work environment - could benefit from more organization and resources.

review_title: One of the most fulfilling jobs I've had.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Provo, UT
pros: The School's values are the best you'll find from any employer. Staff is very caring and, dare I say, spiritual. My work here allowed for much personal growth as I knew that my work was adding to a greater cause.
cons: If working as a student, you are, regrettably slave to Obama care and cannot work longer than 20 hours a week. As a graduate student that limit is raised to 28 hours, but is still a bit of a downer. BYU, however, cannot control or modify that.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pleasant Grove, UT
pros: Flexible hours and good pay.  Get to have the satisfaction of helping students learn and understand basic financial principles. Good coworkers.
cons: Sometimes sitting the the class can be dull. You don't always get the amount of hours that you would like. There was not very much initial training on the onset, you have to learn as you go.

pros:
I love working at BYU as a student because they are very helpful in working around your schedule and being flexible (depending of course on what department you are working for). 
I work side-by-side in a great atmosphere with professionals (experienced full-time employees) and we all have the same goal of providing campus with technology.
cons: There are no downsides for BYU specifically, the downsides are that life gets busy and it's hard to work and study as a student at times.

pros: Great experience as a student working to gain HR experience. The people you work with are amazing and cheerful. Benefits for full-timers are the best you can get.
cons: There are also those who have worked at BYU for a long time and don't really care about anyone else, they seem grumpy. There are also many people there that are oblivious to non-church related experience; they've only been working at BYU, so their church values tend to override their work decisions.

pros: The job was easy and steady. I always knew what to expect when I came in and was always able to accomplish the tasks that customers needed me to.
cons: The job was pretty boring, and the pay wasn't very good. We usually had to print students' homework, so the customers were pretty cranky and rushed.

pros: Management is very open to working around University classes.  The job requires little thinking, I usually listened to talk radio while I worked.  Overtime is never needed.  The direct supervisor is very kind.
cons: The work is very repetitive and pay is average to below-average compared to other jobs on BYU campus.  There is no room for promotion or job growth.

review_title: Great Education experience through coursework and research in BYU's Chemical Engineering Dept.
job_title: PhD Candidate In Chemical Engineering in Provo, UT
pros: Most professors sincerely care about their students personal lifes and research progress. You're giving a lot of autonomy to direct your own research. Most students are given the opportunity to hire and manage undergraduate research assistants. All Master's and PhD candidates are given a stipend.
cons: Still in school! Have limited resources so must work with you have or can afford.

review_title: Generally good experience and learned a lot.
pros:
Pretty relaxed when working under professors
Pay is okay, and you can game on a lot of the computers and they don't mind
cons:
Not very relaxed when working under PhD students
Can get pretty stressful sometimes with classes.

review_title: Awesome to be a grad student here
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Provo, UT
pros: I really enjoy being a grad student research assistant at BYU. It could just be that our lab is really fun to work in, but its full of people who are really enthusiastic about their work, and that kind of enthusiasm is contagious.
cons: It's still just grad student pay? That's expected just about anywhere though, I feel like.

job_title: CS Teachers Assistant in Provo, UT
pros:
-I am a BYU student, so working on campus is perfect for me. I am able to work more hours because I don't have any travel time
-Hours are super flexible. I have to be consistent, but I can essentially work whenever I want
-I get to work directly with professors and glean knowledge from them
cons: I occasionally have to work late nights on the days that projects are due

pros: Great working environment, freedom for creativity is encouraging, and flexible work hours. But I have only been working for them as a student so I don't know what full time employee's are required to do
cons: The pay is not that great on a student level, the work environment can be way too layed back since its Hawaii

pros: Paid to prep and teach Zumba classes, which was amazingly fun. I loved that I got to make up exciting choreography for my students.
cons: Only able to offer about 2-8 hours per week because they try to spread the available classes to as many teachers as possible.

pros: It's a great place to be. Honestly I love BYU so much. People here are so friendly. The environment is really conducive for long term learning.
cons: People can sometimes be annoying. I think that it could be more interesting. Sometimes you have to interact with a lot of zoobies. But hey it's Provo and I'll be leaving soon.

pros: I have loved working for BYU it has been a blast. The culture and the atmosphere has been a great environment to be able to become a better person and help others achieve their goals.
cons: The schedule is a little rough with school. At the MTC they require you to work 20 hours which is kind of difficult with school and tests but we work it out.

review_title: Great place on campus for a student job
pros:
The pay is the highest of most student jobs on campus. 
The social life in the HBLL as a custodian on the bathroom cleaning crew is awesome - you clean in teams not alone.
cons: You are only allowed to work while enrolled in school. It is part time only but can boost your hours in the summer to 40/wk if the hours are available.

pros: they work around school hours. BYU employment is school first then employment. All BYU employers have to work around your school schedule making this a very convenient job for students.
cons: Low hours cap, low pay. They are trying to give as many people as possible jobs and are not worried about rewarding their best employees. This leaves little chance for advancement and growth.

job_title: Food Service Worker in Provo, UT
pros: BYU has a great atmosphere. The managers care about the employees in every aspect. Plus, if you're a good employee-- they give raises every so often.
cons: You start out working lower jobs and it usually stays that way. You can't work your way up usually in the way you can in other jobs. Plus, salary or payment starts at minimum wage for Utah.

pros: BYU offers a ton of convenient and decent paying jobs for students to develop their skills in their chosen field of study while supporting themselves through school.
cons: Job placement can be competitive, and sometimes students early in their education lack the qualifications to be placed anywhere but grounds crew. However, the Office of IT provides several entry-level opportunities for driven students.

review_title: Good training, high expectations, lots of work for not a lot of pay
job_title: Project Manager/TA Supervisor in Provo, UT
pros: The coworkers at BYU are all exceptionally skilled and dedicated to building a positive work environment and helping students to succeed.
cons: There are a lot of challenges that come because employees are swamped with too many things to do.  I wish there would be more of a balance.

review_title: BYU has many great student part-time jobs available. Great School and good culture.
job_title: BYU Freshman Mentoring Mentor in Provo, UT
pros: BYU is a good institution to work for. There is never "layoffs" in student jobs unless someone is failing to perform. Managers tend to be good natured people who genuinely care about you and your life.
cons: Pay is fairly low, which is expected for part-time employment on a university campus. BYU is very conservative, so that affects policy from time to time in ways that may not make sense or are simply ineffective.

review_title: Get paid while you get a degree. Their only interest is in helping you succeed.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Provo, UT
pros: The professors here are sincerely interested in your development, unlike some professors who may only use you to help in publishing research. The wages for graduate students are much better than for undergraduates. They allow you to work independently and at your own pace. Prime situation for self-motivated individuals.
cons: The hands-off management approach of the professors may contribute to you getting behind on research work when your homework load piles up.

review_title: Business Career Center Recruiter Support Team is THE BEST JOB ON CAMPUS!
pros: The mantra of the Business Career Center is Professional - Community - Enable. There is a special environment where all the student employees feel like they are part of a family. We focus on each other's strengths and love to see each other succeed. Great view, great opportunity to gain valuable work experience, and great people.
cons: It can be demanding at times - working extra hours or stressful environment but with the team support its nothing anyone can't handle.

pros: Was a very good job as a student. Pay was great especially for first time as a TA. This is all for the ECEn department, can't say for the others. Though I imagine pay is quite similar for TAs campus wide. I was not given too much of a work load and there were enough other TAs. The students were great to get along with for me. And the professors I worked with were good and willing to help with solutions and explanations.
cons: None that I can think of.

pros: Working as a research assistant has provided flexible hours and a wonderful experience that has allowed me to contribute to cutting edge research.
cons: Working as a research assistant has meant that a majority of my workload is at the discretion of my lead professor. Sometimes the work seems unbalanced.

pros: The values and commitment to education among BYU employees is very high. Supervisors and administration are also willing to accommodate employee's home/family responsibilities.
cons: It can be difficult to move up within a position. If you want to receive more challenging assignments (and the commensurate increase in salary), you will likely have to seek opportunities available elsewhere within the University.

pros: The environment helps me learn new skills and the people are great. People here are very friendly. The challenges I faced allowed me to expand my understanding. My employer and coworkers are very easy to get along with. I set my own hours every four months and I can adjust them when necessary.
cons: The culture here is obviously centered around the LDS Church and everyone who works here has to abide by the standards of the church. This could be seen as a con by some people.

review_title: Great working environment with some of the best people in the world.
job_title: Computer Support Representative in Provo, UT
pros: Beautiful campus, that is always clean.  Strict standards for employees.  If you are LDS (Mormon) you will enjoy it here.  If you are not you may feel a bit strained.
cons: Very few opportunities for promotion.  Stiff competition for jobs,  Bad weather in this region makes travel difficult in the winter.  Parking is difficult, unless you have an "A" parking pass.

review_title: A place where I can make the world better by doing my job better every day
pros:
-Great students
-Moral and clean environment
-BYU invests in the individual - your growth is important to the institution
-Leaders are leaders because they are sacrificing, not because they want to be leaders
cons:
-Pay is not comparable to other academic institutions (lower)
-Parking on campus is challenging
-There is a lot of red tape

review_title: Love the academic environment and ability to make decisions that make a difference.
pros: Independence and good listeners to suggested direction and improvements that can be made.  Great hours.  Small town excellent place to raise a family.  Big University in a small town.  Teton mountains, Yellowstone, nearby for recreation.  Great fishing, skiing, hiking, etc.
cons: Salary could be a bit higher.  Long winters in Rexburg Nov-March below freezing temperatures.

pros: At BYU you will work with some of the smartest, most amazing, kindest people that are out there. Everyone at BYU is hardworking, dedicated, and loves what they do.
cons: Pay scale is significantly lower than what you will see at other companies, however this can be typical at universities. Very strict moral codes which can feel very constrictive. Only work here if you are highly religious.

pros: The work that the office does is awesome. We help multicultural students achieve their dreams in college, recruit students that otherwise might not attend a big university, and provide opportunities to share our culture across a wide campus
cons: The leadership in the office is very disconnected from what the students want and need. They sometimes seem more interested in building their own egos and resumes than accomplishing the office mission.

pros: Hi pay, with rapid and big raises every semester. Usually you can pick your own hours. I'd highly recommend it to anyone in the program.
cons: It can be really stressful if there is a line of students waiting to talk to you, especially if they have problems you can't or aren't allowed to help them with.

pros: It was a very flexible job to do while at school, and the work was interesting sometimes.  The management was very kind as well.
cons: Like other BYU employees, I don't think the management is paid that well and there was not a lot of drive among the student employees.

job_title: Computer Support Representative in Provo, UT
pros: BYU helps you work around your classes to graduate while still keeping out of debt.
cons: There are a few downsides. Since you work as a part time employee you get no benefits. There is a bit of advancement that you can do in the companies, but most jobs or low skilled ones that pay little and don't have chance of advancement. Lastly, you have to leave as soon as you graduate even if you don't have another job, that might be a good thing though.

review_title: Best Student Jobs on BYU Campus
job_title: Social Media Manager in Provo, UT
pros: Library student employees make a generous starting wage, with a 25 cent raise each semester based on performance reviews. The library is a peaceful, fun, fascinating environment, with fun co-workers. Administration and supervisors are very understanding of students' busy schedules. So many interesting jobs available! I have worked in/with several departments, and have been impressed with the quality of staff in all of them.
cons: Some student jobs only have 8am-5pm hours, which can be difficult to work into a full-time school schedule.

pros:
The hours are very flexible for students.
Love the people I work with and the work that we do.
I love developing content for online courses.
cons:
We can hit slow times occasionally, but most of the time we keep pretty busy.
The work I do can be challenging, but I have learned a lot in this job.

pros: Great job, Flexible with school, and great bosses. They know you are a student first and make every allowance reasonable to allow you to be successful do not abuse their niceness though.
cons: If you have a problem with being dirty don't. There is little to nothing bad about this job if you work hard and do what you say you will.

pros: Usually I am able to work on homework or other needs while i run the lab. Fairly chill atmosphere. Can learn a lot
cons: Recently the ability to work on other projects or homework while running the lab has changed so i have had to reduce my hours in order to do my homework.

job_title: Academic Peer Advisor in Rexburg, ID
pros: It's a great environment that is friendly and supportive. Policy is constantly changing and evolving, and the University really focuses on giving students the most experience possible.
cons: Hours are limited to less that 20 a week, and with some departments constant turn-over, it can get frustrating working with people who don't properly understand or portray policy.

job_title: MTC Custodial Supervisor in Provo, UT
pros: The environment is fantastic, it is great to work with missionaries, and the benefits package is unbeatable. Plus, if you are LDS, instant job satisfaction.
cons: Not very much communication between Ecclesiastical and Temporal departments. Sometimes they are slow to upgrade or buy new equipment.

pros: It was an easy job
cons: I would probably have a better review had I had a better manager. The manager I worked under was TERRIBLE. I cant express that enough. She played favorites, was not fair, and kept nothing confidential. It seemed that she was more concerned with being friends with the employees than doing well at her job. Nothing was confidential and any gossip was started by her which made it seem more than okay to do. She would complain about staff she didn't like and everyone who when someone was going to get fired and why. She made it a very hostile place to work, especially if you weren't a "favorite". I would discourage anyone from working under her.

pros: BYU offers several opportunities for you to try new things and to be able to have a schedule that fits your class schedule.
cons: BYU is the lowest paying employer for my job sector.  The maximum hourly pay for a student employee is $15. If you just want to cut rent and pay for food, it should be fine.

review_title: I am fortunate to work with great students and teach subjects that I really love.
pros: Very bright students, great physical facilities and computers, supportive colleagues, fairly good technical support, freedom to develop course content, encouragement toward personal and professional growth
cons: Capricious departmental leadership, over emphasis on student evaluations, some stifling of dissent,  hypocritical "support" for teaching but true evaluation based on scholarship,

review_title: A great opportunity to make a meaningful impact
pros: One of the best things about BYU-Idaho is that student employees are empowered to do more and have more responsibilities than may be given in any other university.
cons: One downside is that there's a feeling of separation between the student employees and the other employees at the university. The other thing is that you will rarely get to know any management more than two levels above you.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Provo, UT
pros: I worked at BYU as a research assistant while a student in order to gain research experience and help pay for tuition and other expenses. It was exactly what I needed, and paid well compared to other student jobs. It was very flexible, I could set my own hours to work around my work schedule.
cons: The downside with working at BYU is that after graduation I can no longer continue my job, but that's generally a given when you work as a research assistant

pros:
Great people, great atmosphere, great opportunities.  I love it here.  I highly recommend this university to anyone interested in acquiring a high quality education, and great on-campus research opportunities.

There are many great resources for help, including counseling services, to help students.
cons: If you are taking classes, depending on your major, the course load can be rather demanding.  It honestly can be stressful. Thankfully, there are great resources available to help students.  There are great sources of support.

job_title: Development Team Assistant in Canandaigua, NY
pros: You get to work with some of the greatest people here on campus!  Great work environment, understanding supervisors, and it's pretty individual work (no micromanagement).
cons: Because it's a campus job, the pay isn't always where it could be, but if you find the right supervisor and work to do, that can be taken care of.

job_title: Night Lock-up Security in Rexburg, ID
pros: Great place to work. Very flexible with class schedule. This is one of the most desired jobs on the campus. Management is easy going. Just show up on-time and be proactive there.
cons: Only allowed to work 20 hrs. Other than that, it was the perfect college job! I would recommend it to any of my friends to check out this job!

pros: Being a graduate research assistant anywhere won't do much besides pay the most essential bills, but this is a good place to do it. Generally supported faculty and good balance
cons: Of course, if you're a graduate student you realize that you're investing in the future and putting off a future payoff - so you're not going to make a lot of money

pros: Good Company, take care of employees, pay scale is high, employees are happy here because of the excellent environment. There is lots diversity. Job selection is on fair basis. There are no means of biases.
cons: This is not a very popular Company. Some people are very disgusting that destroys the work capabilities of others. recruitment is not very frequent.

pros: I got exposed to new concepts that I wouldn't have learned in a classroom. It helped me develop critical thinking skills.
cons: Because I knew very little about the research I was conducting, it felt very directed. When it wasn't directed enough, things didn't happen smoothly. When it was directed enough, it felt like a do this, then do that kind of situation.

review_title: Review of being a statistics 221 teacher assistant at BYU
pros: The students are awesome, most of the faculty will do anything to help you, and you really feel like you're helping people.
cons: The pay was incredibly low compared to off-capmus work and you often had too much work and too few hours to complete it.

job_title: Subject Specialist Librarian in Provo, UT
pros: Excellent support for professional development. A generally positive work environment. A shared sense of mission and unified organizational culture. Reasonable compensation.
cons: As with any academic institution, tenure can lead to complacency among senior employees. The metrics used in evaluating success do not always align with the stated organizational mission.

review_title: I loved working at BYU. It is a great environment to learn and grow. There is nothing that I would change.
pros: Learn and grow. I learned so many new skills and became proficient in PHP, MYSQL and javascript.
cons: Sometimes the projects that I worked on were a little boring, dealing with Drupal. But most of the time it was great.

pros: You get to make your own schedule. Working with the students and helping them to understand the material is one of the most rewarding jobs that you can ever have.
cons: They have an ever growing online program which means that there are more and more students that need help online. Tutoring students online can be a challenge.

job_title: Hazardous Materials Manager in Elk Ridge, UT
